content.webTitle: No Activity review – nothing happens, but that’s the point of this hilarious cop comedy

fields.headline: No Activity review – nothing happens, but that’s the point of this hilarious cop comedy
fields.bodyText: It is not the first time it has been done in a comedy – a conversation unintentionally overheard by the subject of the conversation because, unknown to the conversers, an electronic device is on. Baby monitors are a common way to go about it. This is a particularly lovely example of it, though, delivered not via baby monitor, but over police radio. Maybe lovely isn’t the right word. Hilarious is better. Detectives Hendy and Stokes are in a squad car on a long stakeout – that’s the central premise of BBC Two’s No Activity – and, as you might guess from the title, they are not that busy. They have just radio-met April, the new officer in the control room, and played a mean trick on her: pretending to be under attack from armed hoodlums, and requiring urgent backup, then getting shot. “She sounds nice, doesn’t she?” says Stokes afterwards, playing Cupid (again) with his single partner/best mate. Hendy says he doesn’t want a nice April, he wants a filthy April, and he sets off on one about exactly what kind of April he would like (Parisian, with a bit of medieval) and what he would like to do with her (a lot). He is getting more and more carried away with the fantasy and even starts acting it out. Stokes joins in until Carol, April’s deadpan boss in dispatch, finally interrupts: “Car 72, you’re still on.” Stokes had the button resting against his thigh … Better than “God, I hate so-and-so” over the baby monitor at a dinner party, no? Because it pushes the same thing a little further, into a riskier – and more risque – territory. And No Activity, the first comedy on Aussie streaming service Stan, does that – it bumbles along. There’s not much going on – it is just a couple of mates on the job, blokey banter, and then suddenly they’ll go a little bit further. Some will probably say they go too far. Before the April thing, they were wondering, if you were a Siamese twin (not conjoined, note), which hand you would masturbate with. The one connected with your head? Or would you use the other one, because then it would be like it was someone else? And would you have to ask the other head’s permission if you wanted to use their arm: “Would you mind jerking us off” … and, suddenly, there are all sorts of ethical and philosophical issues on the subject for them to discuss. It’s bloody funny. And also utterly believable. If you were stuck doing nothing for a long time with someone with whom you got along pretty well – even if, at times, you irritated the crap out of each other – you would, eventually, get around to the conjoined self-pleasure debate. You have probably had it already. Here are a few other things I like about No Activity: 1. Hendy’s sarcasm. “Oh, then something really weird happened?” he says, when Stokes, halfway through a story that’s already really weird, about an encounter he had with an old man in a hot tub, says that then something really weird happened. 2. The concrete dolphin on the back seat of the car. “What dolphin?” says Stokes, sarkily. 3. Carol’s world-weariness and unpredictability. 4. April’s secret (it comes out in episode two, that she killed a man. April’s a dark horse). 5. The bit where Carol tells April: “Assaulting a horse is assaulting a member of the police force.” 6. How Stokes plans to get rid of the Black Dog that has wife, Wendy, by the throat – by giving her a child. 7. And how he won’t need to reverse a vasectomy, because he never had a vasectomy, even if he does – Hendy thinks – have a “vasectomy face”. 8. Amusing criminal lowlifes Bruce and Jimmy, in the warehouse, being staked out, though they don’t know it. 9. Jimmy also doesn’t know who his father is, although he is on a mission to find out and he has narrowed it down to most of the men in Australia. 10. Activity! Bruce gets shot, by Stokes, uncharacteristically. That’ll do, for now. There is a US adaptation of this, executive produced by Will Ferrell and Adam McKay. I don’t really want to see it. I like No Activity – and I think it belongs – as it is here, in Australia. Get involved.
